repnme.cdata!: Improving competitiveness across sectors in Honduras

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is responsible for advancing
            various reforms that have improved the Honduras business
            climate and competitiveness and directly benefitted over
            1,400 micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs). The vast
            majority of reforms and impacts from project activities will
            continue after the close of the project. In some cases, the
            government has already taken ownership of project
            activities, such as the reforms in the competition and
            consumer protection agencies. In other cases, the private
            beneficiaries, such as matching grant recipients or local
            competitiveness participants, are leveraging the project’s
            investments to continue to improve their businesses or to
            obtain other financing.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Enhancing Competitiveness :
            Trade Facilitation and Productivity Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Enhancing
            Competitiveness : Trade Facilitation and Productivity
            Improvement Project for Honduras were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory; the risk to development
            outcome was moderate; the Bank's performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and the Borrower's performance
            was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: an overly complex design with too many components
            and activities leads to a project that is difficult to
            implement, supervise, and evaluate. A complex design also
            makes it challenging to establish an overall objective that
            is focused and near impossible to identify clear Project
            Development Objective (PDO) indicators. Procurement
            practices should be applied in a predictable way. Housing
            the Project Implementation Unit (PIU) in an entity outside
            of the government has both advantages and disadvantages. It
            is important to design realistic sustainability mechanisms
            for technology centers (CITEs) from the outset of the
            project. Risks that buildings constructed with project
            resources are used for purposes outside the scope of the
            legal agreement need to be carefully managed.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Enhancing Competitiveness :
            Trade Facilitation and Productivity Improvement Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Enhancing
            Competitiveness: Trade Facilitation and Productivity
            Improvement Project is to increase the productivity of the
            Honduran private sector, thereby improving Honduras'
            competitiveness. This improvement should be driven mainly by
            an improvement in microeconomic competitiveness ranking
            (business environment and companies' performance), for
            which the goal is that Honduras should move from 78th (in
            2003) to 65th (in 2008). The macroeconomic index; which is
            the second determinant of the overall competitiveness
            ranking and is outside the scope of this project, is also
            expected to improve based on the Government's planned
            macroeconomic reforms. The extension will allow programmed
            activities of the credit to be completed. The activities
            were delayed as a consequence of the events following the
            June 28, 2009 removal of the President of Honduras. The
            project implementation unit has prepared an action plan,
            calendar, and monitoring indicators for the completion of
            activities by end-December 2010.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Trade Facilitation and
            Productivity Enhancement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper introduces the
            following changes in the Honduras Trade Facilitation and
            Productivity Improvement Project, and any accompanying
            amendments to the project's legal documents. The
            changes make more explicit and clarify the financing of
            works that were envisaged in the previous restructuring of
            July 17, 2007. Specifically, the construction of the
            national metrology laboratory will be added to a
            sub-component and the construction of a technology center
            will be made more explicit in another sub-component. This
            project paper also describes all of the works being financed
            by the Project, given that previous amendments have expanded
            the number of works from what was originally foreseen in the
            project appraisal document (PAD). Finally, some adjustments
            are made to the output indicators. A reallocation of loan
            proceeds and partial extension of the project closing date
            are being processed separately in line with Bank guidelines.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Enhancing Competitiveness :
            Trade Facilitation and Productivity Improvement Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Trade
            Facilitation and Productivity Enhancement Project is to
            increase the productivity of the Honduran private sector,
            thereby improving Honduras's competitiveness and
            economic growth, which will in turn increase employment and
            reduce the poverty level. The immediate objective of the
            project is to improve Honduras' investment climate and
            local firms' capacity to export in order to prepare
            Honduras to take advantage of trade opportunities under
            existing and new Trade Promotion Agreements. The objective
            of the Environmental Assessment Report and Environmental
            Management Plan is to present based on an analysis of
            various aspects of environmental issues, an analysis of
            potential environmental impacts and the measures required
            for ensuring environmental sustainability of investments. In
            general the activities or works proposed will not cause
            social and environmental significant impacts due to the
            scale of the work areas and human consolidated intervention.
            However, due to the indirect impacts that certain activities
            generate, the impact can be significant. Activities likely
            to generate environmental and social impacts include:
            Selection of areas for the location of the workshops or work
            areas for materials or hazardous substances; Excessive use
            of chemicals to improve productivity; Transport and storage
            of raw materials to the workshop or work area.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Enhancing Competitiveness :
            Trade Facilitation and Productivity Improvement Project :
            indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Enhancing Competitiveness - Trade Facilitation and
            Productivity Improvement Project for Honduras is to increase
            the productivity of the Honduran private sector, improving
            Honduras' competitiveness and economic growth, which
            will increase employment and reduce the poverty level.
            Negative measures include: insecurity on tenure of property
            and the territory in which they live. This sense of
            insecurity is compound by the lack of property titles, the
            invasion of their land, intrusion of estrangers into their
            territory, and harassment to sell the land;  lack of
            policies, programs, and projects for the sustainable
            management of the natural resources in their ancestral
            lands, and community 'invisibility' on decision
            affecting the exploitation of these natural resources; lack
            of alternative training programs and opportunities; and lack
            of women participation in the organizational processes.
            Mitigation measures include: the implementation must be
            aware of previous experiences with the community to identify
            lessons learned and capture proven successful experiences.
            Good relations must be developed between the implementing
            team and the indigenous communities. The interventions must
            be based on the participation of competent public and
            private organizations familiar with the projects objectives
            and recognized and accepted by the communities. The
            intervention must contribute to answer the expressed needs
            of the communities. Finally, a participative evaluation
            system should assess the achievement of the goals set for
            the intervention and learn from the experience.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Trade Facilitation and
            Productivity Enhancement Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Trade Facilitation
            and Productivity Enhancement Project for Honduras is to
            improve the Borrower's investment climate and local
            firms' capacity to export in order to prepare the
            Borrower to benefit from trade opportunities under existing
            and new trade promotion agreements. The project
            restructuring aims at addressing some minor shortcomings in
            the original project design, which were identified in a July
            2006 midterm review and in two supervision missions in
            October 2006 and April 2007. The corresponding adjustments
            are expected to remove minor roadblocks to project
            implementation. In particular, the restructuring includes,
            first, small changes in the set of activities to be financed
            within certain components. These changes are aimed at
            eliminating activities that are no longer viable or
            necessary and to add others that are deemed critical to
            generate the expected project outcomes and to facilitate the
            achievement of the project's development objectives.
            Second, the restructuring includes revisions in the
            expenditure categories to be financed within existing
            activities (e.g. adding the financing of minor works or
            equipment in activities where only consultancies had been
            included in the original budget). Changes are also proposed
            in the overall maximum amounts to be financed within each
            expenditure category.  Third, the restructuring also
            includes changes in relevant definitions and loan covenants.
